captions.text:
So say you're me and
you're in math class

and you're trying to
ignore the teacher

and doodle Fibonacci
spirals, while simultaneously

trying to fend off
the local greenery.

Only, you become
interested in something

that the teacher
says by accident,

and so you draw too many
squares to start with.

So you cross some out,
but cross out too many,

and then the teacher
gets back on track,
and the moment is over.

So oh well, might
as well try and just
do the spiral from here.

So you make a three
by three square.

And here's a four by four, and
then seven, and then 11 This

works because then you've
got a spiral of squares.

So you write down the
numbers, 1, 3, 4, 7, 11, 18.

It's kind of like the Fibonacci
series, because 1 plus 3 is 4,
3 plus 4 is 7, and so on.

Or maybe it starts at 2 plus
1, or negative 1 plus 2.

Either way, it's a
perfectly good series.

And it's got another similarity
with the Fibonacci series.

The ratios of consecutive
numbers also approach Phi.
OK.

So, a lot of plants have
Fibonacci numbers of spirals,

but to understand
how they do it,

we can learn from
the exceptions.

This pine cone that has
seven spirals one way,

and eleven the other, might
be showing Lucas numbers.

And since Fibonacci numbers
and Lucas numbers are related,
maybe that explains it.

One theory was that plants
get Fibonacci numbers

by always growing new parts
a Phi-th of a circle around.

What angle would
give Lucas numbers?

In this pine cone, each
new pine cone-y thing

is about 100 degrees
around from the last.

We're going to need
a Lucas angle-a-tron.

It's easy to get a 90
degree angle-a-tron,

and if I take a third
of a third of that,

that's a ninth of 90, which
is another 10 degrees.
There.

Now you can use it to
get spiral patterns

like what you see on
the Lucas number plants.

It's an easy way to
grow Lucas spirals,

if plants have an
internal angle-a-tron.

Thing is, 100 is
pretty far from 137.5.

If plants were somehow
measuring angle,

you'd think the
anomalous ones would

show angles close to
a Phi-th of a circle.
Not jump all the way to 100.

Maybe I'd believe different
species use different angles,

but two pine cones
from the same tree?

Two spirals on the
same cauliflower?

And that's not the
only exception.

A lot of plants don't
grow spirally at all.
Like this thing.

With leaves growing
opposite from each other.

And some plants have
alternating leaves,

180 degrees from
each other, which

is far from both Phi
and Lucas angles.

And you could say that these
don't count because they

have a fundamentally
different growth pattern,

and are in a different
class of plant or something,

but wouldn't it be
even better if there

were one simple reason
for all of these things?

These variations are a good
clue that maybe these plants get

this angle, and
Fibonacci numbers,

as a consequence of some other
process and not just because it

mathematically optimizes
sunlight exposure if the sun is

right overhead, which
it pretty much never is,

and if the plan are
perfectly facing straight up,
which they aren't.
So how do they do it?

Well, you could
try observing them.
That would be like science.

If you zoom in on the tip of
a plant, the growing part,

there's this part
called the meristem.

That's where new
plant bits form.

The biggest plant bits
where the first to form off

the meristem, and the little
ones around the center
are newer.

As the plants grow, they get
pushed away from the meristem,
but they all started there.

The important part is
that a science observer

would see the plant
bits pushing away,

not just from the meristem,
but from each other.

A couple physicists
once tried this thing

where they dropped drops
of a magnetized liquid
in a dish of oil.

The drops repelled each
other, kind of like plant bits

do, and were attracted
to the edge of the dish,

just like how plant bits
move away from the center.

The first couple jobs would
head in opposite directions

from each other, but then the
third was repelled by both,

but pushed farther by the
more recent, and closer, drop.

It, and each new
drop, would set off

at a Phi angle relative
to the drop before,

and the drops ended up forming
Fibonacci numbers spirals.

So all a plant would
need to do to get

Fibonacci numbers
spirals is figure out

how to make the plant
bits repel each other.

We don't know all the details,
but here's what we do know.

There's a hormone that
tells plant bits to grow.

A plant bit might use up
the hormone around it,

but there's more
further away, so it'll
grow in that direction.

That makes plant bits
move out from the meristem
after they form.

Meanwhile, the meristem
keeps forming new plant bits,

and they're going
to grow in places

that aren't too
crowded, because that's

where there's the
most growth hormone.

This leads them to
move further out

into the space left by the
other outward moving plant bits.

And once everything gets
locked into a pattern,
it's hard to get out of it.

Because there's no
way for this plant

bit to wander off
unless there were

an empty space with a
trail of plant hormone
to lead it out of its spot.

But if there were, all
the nearer plant bits

would use up the hormone
grow to fill in the space.

Mathematicians and programmers
made their own simulations,
and found the same thing.

The best way to fit new
things in with the most space,

has them pop up at that angle,
not because the plant knows

about the angle,
but because that's

where the most
hormone has built up.

Once it gets started, it's
a self perpetuating cycle.

All these flower
bits are doing is

growing where there's
the most room for them.

The rest happens
auto-mathically.

It's not weird that all these
plants show Fibonacci numbers.

It would be weird
if they didn't.
It had to be this way.

The best thing
about that theory is

that it explains why Lucas
pine cones would happen.

If something goes
a bit differently

in the very beginning,
the meristem

will settle into a different,
but stable, pattern

of where there's the most
room to add new plant bits.
That is 100 degrees away.

It even explains
alternating leaf patterns.

If the leaves are
far enough apart,

relative to how much
growth hormone they like,

that these leaves don't
have any repelling

force with each other, then
all this leaf cares about

is being farthest away from
the two above and below

it, which makes 180
degrees optimal.

And when leaves
grow in pairs that

are opposite each other,
the answer of where there's

the most room for
both of those leaves,

is at 90 degrees from
the one below it.

And if you look hard,
you can discover
even more unusual patterns.

The dots on the neck
of this whatever-it-is,

come in spirals of 14 and
22, which maybe is like
double the Lucas numbers.

And this pine cone has 6 and
10, double Fibonacci numbers.

So how is a pineapple
like a pine cone?

What do daisies and Brussels
sprouts have in common?

It's not the numbers they
show, it's how they grow.

This pattern is not just
useful, not just beautiful,
it's inevitable.

This is why science and
mathematics are so much fun.

You discover things that seem
impossible to be true, and then

get to figure out why it's
impossible for them not to be.

To get this far in our
understanding of these things,

it took the combined effort
of mathematicians, physicists,
botanists, and biochemists.

And we've certainly
learned a lot.

But there's much more
to be discovered.

Maybe if you keep
doodling in math class,
you can help figure it out.

title: Doodling in Math: Spirals, Fibonacci, and Being a Plant [Part 3 of 3]

comments.text:
But aren't animals are full of Fibonacci too? The length of our finger 
bones relative to one another seem to be at the ϕ ratio, the average height 
of our belly buttons compared to our average overall height, as Leonardo Da 
Vinci pointed out. Dragon fly wingspan compared to length. Sea shells are a 
common example. And how can all of us different life forms be full of ϕ and 
still look so different. I don't think I look like a pineapple. But maybe 
I'm just not vain enough to take credit were it's due.﻿

comments.text:
+Paul Chi I forget about timezones, it's 5 for me.
But to that point, I think it's amatter of us having different philosophies 
on life. I see things as existing more on their own (although not 
completely independently) and you more in terms of relationships to other 
things, both of which are fine outlooks. Back to my earlier point, 
postulation. G'night Paul.
comments.author: Tröggâçom Càctüs

comments.text:
You are quite charming. I don't mind you calling me simple. I simply don't 
think that you can validly say of yourself, 'I'm me' and 'no relation to 
anyone or anything else'. That doesn't make any sense at all and can't 
possibly be true. You are always a son; its not a social construct, its 
biological, etc. Chat later... gotta go to bed !
comments.author: Paul Chi

comments.text:
+Paul Chi Postulation again. If you asked me who I am, I'd say I'm me. No 
relation to anyone or anything else, unless you pester me to give yous such 
answers. I see these relationships as social constructs that we use to 
model the world around us, physical or otherwise, so as to better 
understand it. It may sound like I'm calling you simple, or stupid, or 
generally like I'm being condescending, and while that may very well be 
true that it's the message I'm conveying, that's not my intent. (wow that 
was a long disclaimer)

TL;DR I find relations like that to be arbitrary and human-drawn. I also 
hate taxonomy for the same reason.
comments.author: Tröggâçom Càctüs

comments.text:
You make some great points, like perhaps "everything is sentient and we 
don't recognize it...". I think perhaps that people opposed vehemently to 
the God notion have issues with their fathers !!
I actually believe that the God argument is the reasonable one because its 
based on common sense. The fact that when I ask you who you are, and you 
say I'm a father or a mother or a daughter or a son or a sister or a 
brother (alll relationahl terms) indicates to me that we live in a 
relational universe; that its how the universe works. In fact, this is your 
reality, not numbers or theories about the origin of the universe, but 
facts about the key relatioships that shape who you are. There isn't a 
coherent scientific explanation of the universe and everything. You are 
better off starting from your own experience.
comments.author: Paul Chi

comments.text:
+Tröggâçom Càctüs

If you were better informed, you wouldn't need to make up statistics in 
order to dismiss a reasonable discussion with a simple and clear conclusion 
(simple and clear if one employs reason): there is absolutely no evidence 
for any god.
comments.author: Mitchell Davis

comments.text:
Also, 99.9 to 100% of the atheistic/theistic argument boils down to 
postulation, so arguing about it is kind of pointless, at least for 
non-philosophers.
comments.author: Tröggâçom Càctüs

comments.text:
+Paul Chi That's a good question that I won't even pretend to try and 
answer in a text box. I've given a lot of thought to where sentience came 
from, and I still don't have an answer. But to your point about intent, I 
see no reason why anything we see now needed intention to be created. I 
think people see creation in nature not because it was created, but because 
we create to replicate nature and therefore, nature looks created. Much 
like some people, typically in reference to television or related, say that 
X is a shameless ripoff of Y, when Y was created so as to be like X. They 
were exposed more to Y first, so they think X was meant to be like Y, even 
though X came first and y was inspired by X. If this makes any sense. So 
I'm not sure of any other beings, physical or otherwise, capable of intent 
or longing or anything else you listed, but I see no solid reason 
personally as to why they must. Perhaps we simply haven't found them yet, 
or everything is sentient and we don't recognize it because it's so 
different from our own sentience. I don't pretend to understand, but those 
are my uneducated guesses.
comments.author: Tröggâçom Càctüs

comments.text:
+Paul Chi

" the designed purposeful world, "

The universe is structured, *not designed.*

To conflate the two is blatant dishonesty.

"Randomness or God"

Again, blatantly dishonest: you've knowingly constructed a false dichotomy.

" I find everywhere evidence of INTENTION."

Liar. If you do, you can prove it; you can't, so you do not.

By definition one cannot determine that a thing is designed if there is no 
natural state to compare with, as design is determined by contrasting 
nature with what has been knowingly designed. To claim that there is some 
sort of design to the universe, you have to first abandoned reason.
comments.author: Mitchell Davis

comments.text:
Cool. I don't believe in hell beyond the one our species seems to be good 
at creating on this planet.
I'm with you on the "patterns/beauty in nature means God" argument is 
unconvincing. 
But the notion that INTENTION only applies to human creation; most of what 
can be seen in our environment; the designed purposeful world, and not to 
anything else in the universe; not to the vastly more impressive creation 
that contextualises our own works... that doesn't make any sense to me. 
Nothing comes into being without passion, longing, desire, energy, 
direction, force, will, INTENT. Its a bit much to suppose that only humans 
have these qualities. We are part of nature. Why would we possess qualities 
that were not found universally?
comments.author: Paul Chi

comments.text:
I find the "patterns/beauty in nature means God"* argument unconvincing, 
mainly because we (as a species) developed in the world and got used to the 
patterns we saw in the world. When we see a field as pretty and paint it, 
it's not evidence of God being at work (to my eyes), it's just 
demonstrating that we've grown to see beauty as what we see in nature. 
Nature isn't beautiful, beauty is nature.

*this is a simplification of what most people say, including yourself

Edit: I should add, thank you for not being rude about it and saying "JESUS 
CHRIST IS LORD AND YOU MUST ACCEPT HIM OR BURN IN HELL FOREVER" like most 
people talking about religion on the internet seem to.
comments.author: Tröggâçom Càctüs

comments.text:
Intriguing; the cause of everything; Randomness or God; unknowable 
opposition; a ridiculous choice. I find everywhere evidence of INTENTION. 
Big R and Big G don't fit.

comments.text:

You are conflating structure with design, and whether or not you're doing 
that intentionally, that is dishonest. If you want to claim that evolution 
proves god, then you have to provide evidence instead of just making the 
declaration.

Furthermore, opinions are not inherently worthy of respect. In science, 
ideas are afforded "respect" based upon the evidence. Respecting all 
opinions means throwing science out the window.

People deserve respect; ideas do not.

comments.author: Ryan Duncan

comments.text:
5:18  Do you mean this one? Sorry, but it is not a Crassula, it is the 
inner part of a Magnolia Grandiflora's flower, its seedpod. It is where, 
after the flower dies, the little red fruits of the Magnolia are stored and 
eventually pop out of it.

comments.author: Patrick Meath

comments.text:
Right, do you know how many years I've been seeing this stuff without 
knowing the why of it?  Because it leaves Nature with room to work.  Always 
room for one more.  It may seem self-evident now, but I find solace in 
knowing it took more than one bright person or discipline to put all this 
together.  I'd like to thank you personally for artfully explaining this to 
me.  I can honestly say, "I get it," now, thanks to you.  So, how did you 
get a shorter attention span than me, anyway?﻿

comments.author: Scott Evans

comments.text:
This was brilliantly done!

So perhaps a little food for thought:  I happened across an article dated 
from 2010 that noticed Phi on the quantum level.  Here's the article, if 
you're curious:  
http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/01/100107143909.htm

This caused me to ponder something I heard Sir Martin Rees say in a lecture 
I watched on YouTube (paraphrased), "Quantum physics and General Relativity 
do not affect each other, but if you wound the clock back to the point of 
the singularity, where the universe was tiny, then quantum physics would 
affect the large."

It's just an idea, and by no means a theory, but perhaps we see this 
pattern because, on the quantum level, it was fundamental to how everything 
started...?  Hmm...﻿
